questions.question: Who were the patricians in the early Roman Republic?
options: Wealthy merchants from Greece
Rome's aristocratic families who held power since the Kingdom period
Soldiers who served in the army
Religious priests and priestesses
questions.text_reference: Section 3: Who Were the Patricians and Plebeians

questions.question: Which group made up the majority of Rome's population in the early Republic?
options: Patricians
Slaves
Plebeians
Etruscan settlers
questions.text_reference: Section 3: Who Were the Patricians and Plebeians

questions.question: What was the primary political grievance of plebeians in the early Republic?
options: They were forced to pay excessive taxes to support the patrician elite
They were required to serve in the military far more frequently than patricians
They were legally prohibited from owning land and could only lease property
They were excluded from holding major political offices and had limited influence in government

questions.question: In what year did plebeians stage their first major secession (refusal to serve in the army)?
options: 509 BCE
494 BCE
450 BCE
445 BCE
questions.text_reference: Section 4: The First Secession of the Plebs

questions.question: What new office was created in 494 BCE to protect plebeian interests?
options: Praetor
Aedile
Tribune
Censor
questions.text_reference: Section 4: The Creation of the Tribune of the Plebs

questions.question: What special power did tribunes possess that no other magistrate had?
options: They could unilaterally declare war against neighboring nations without Senate approval
They could veto any action by other magistrates to protect plebeian interests
They could execute criminals and impose capital punishment without legal trial
They could directly control all Senate meetings and prevent magistrate assemblies
questions.text_reference: Section 4: The Creation of the Tribune of the Plebs

questions.question: What does the term 'sacrosanctus' mean when applied to tribunes?
options: They were required to perform daily religious sacrifices on behalf of Rome
They were given special armed guards and protection by a dedicated security force
They were sacred and inviolableâ€”anyone who physically harmed them could be killed with impunity
They held the authority to approve and regulate all religious ceremonies throughout Rome
questions.text_reference: Section 4: The Creation of the Tribune of the Plebs

questions.question: Why was the ability to refuse military service such a powerful plebeian tactic?
options: Rome was constantly at war and depended heavily on plebeian soldiers for survival
Rome had no professional standing army available to replace the plebeian soldiers
Patrician aristocrats themselves fought in all battles and could not lead without plebeians
The Senate could not hold meetings or make any decisions without military support

questions.question: Which of the following was NOT one of the early plebeian demands?
options: Access to magistracies and high political offices like the consulship
Access to priesthoods and positions of religious authority in Rome
Complete elimination of the Senate as a governing body
Protection and legal safeguards against creditors enslaving debtors

questions.question: What economic problem particularly threatened plebeian freedom in the early Republic?
options: Inability to trade goods with foreign merchants and neighboring city-states
Excessive military conscription requiring plebeians to serve too often in armies
Strict restrictions on farming and agriculture practiced by plebeian families
Debt slavery where creditors could enslave debtors who could not repay loans
questions.text_reference: Section 4: The Crisis - Debt Slavery and Land Disputes
